utterances: Standing under black umbrellas were two blonde, 28-year-old, identical twins both visibly pregnant.
Christina and Catherine McCabe run the McCabe and McCabe Design Company.
We're a new business.
And I think for us, it would be a tremendous amount of publicity and also just confirmation of our talents.
Further down the line was Dr. Gary Swanson, who came all the way from Calgary in Canada.
He's a doctor.
I do radiology.
What are you doing sitting on the designer line being judged by Architectural Digest?
Well, I built my own house and I'm proud of it.
And it's personal pride that brings me here.
Six judges sit inside the building on the 14th floor, everyone gets about five minutes for the judge, and the judges are the editors and art directors of the magazine.
Dr. Swanson's house has high ceilings, wrought iron work everywhere, and views of the Calgary skyline.
He's interviewed by Paige Rense, the editor-in-chief of Architectural Digest.
This is a house I built in Calgary up on the hill.
You designed this house?
Yes.
Did you work with a local architect, contractor, or...
No, I was the contractor.
Oh.
The entrance hall is a two-storey space, is that correct?
Yes, yes.
It's beautifully done.
This looks very good.
Thank you.
You want to give up radiology?
No. I need to do radiology to pay for all of this.
Meanwhile, the McCabe twins are showing the house they designed in East Hampton to the magazine's art director Jeff Nemeroff, who flips through the photographs.
It's clean.
That it feels like the Hamptons, you know.
It does.
Very nice.
Semifinalists will be chosen in New York, in Houston, in South Florida, and in Southern California.
Finalists will be featured in the magazine and the public can vote for their favorites.
Back on the line, I walked up to Phil Kennedy-Grant, an architect from New Jersey, and asked who he thinks besides his fellow professionals, reads Architectural Digest.
Nobody reads it.
They all look at the pictures.
(SOUNDBITE OF LAUGHTER)
Whenever I look at Architectural Digest, I look at it and I say, all these places don't look like anything lives there.
Absolutely.
You know?
That's correct.
I couldn't live in any of those, you know.
One thing out of place, forget it.
But whether or not you could listen them, people definitely want to look at them.
Margo Adler, NPR News, New York.
As David Greene just reported, Paul Wolfowitz or his representatives are engaged at this hour in discussions over his resignation as World Bank president.
NPR's Tom Gjelten is following this story and joins us now.
President Bush sounded as if he might have been saying farewell to Paul Wolfowitz just then.
Is he on the verge of resigning?
Michele, yeah, he's definitely going.

There is this shape of a deal, at least there would be a communique from the executive board of the World Bank, the core of which says - or would say - Wolfowitz has offered his resignation, and it is accepted.
Of course, it's got to say a lot more than that, and it's the language that goes with that that's under discussion and has been now off and on for two days.
Basically, I think the big issue is whether there's any reference in here to Wolfowitz conduct or misconduct as bank president.
Wolfowitz would like to be basically exonerated for this issue of the pay raise for his girlfriend.
He'd like to say that it was a misunderstanding, but the board members really don't want to go that far, so there is a negotiation.
One source in the board told me the final communique will finally say something to the effect, we acknowledge that President Wolfowitz acted in good faith.
The communique may say the ethics committee wasn't clear enough in its instructions about how to handle this pay raise.
But this negotiation is incredibly difficult.
You'd think they were negotiating a security council resolution here.
Difficult and protracted, so when - once they finally do reach an agreement, would Paul Wolfowitz stay on for a while or leave immediately?
Well, that's another thing that has to be negotiated.
As I understand it, there are two possibilities.
One is that his resignation would be immediate.
The other one is that it would take effect only in a couple of months or when there is a new successor.
However...
Immediate but take effect in a couple of months.
Well, in that case, what he would do is go on administrative leave for the duration.
So in either case, he would be finished.
Any idea who might replace him?
Michele, the problem with that is it is much bigger than just the individual who can lead the bank.
It brings up the whole issue of does the United States retain its prerogative, is it an American?
You know, it has really escalated into a whole geopolitical thing, and that's why I think they're going to work through that very slowly.

Just quickly, Tom, do you get a sense that they're even allowing themselves to engage in those discussions, to look ahead about his - to talk about his replacement until they work out the conditions of this deal?
No, in fact, I've asked that to people, Michele, and they say, right now, they are so focused on the resignation itself that they really haven't gotten to that point yet.
Thank you, Tom.
Thank you.
That was NPR's Tom Gjelten.
(Soundbite of music)
It's Memorial Day weekend, time to reflect on the men and women who died serving in our military.
For Ricardo Garcia of Lansing, Mich., that defines his idea of patriotism.
We had a lot of people that fought for our freedom - that I recognize that the freedom we have now today is established because of the many lives that have died for us to have it.
